comment: it’s possible (but it’s not totally ok, the subject of 2nd sentence could be understood as another person). Needs list-like intonation
like ‘either…or…’ in English

Intonation determines whether the sentence has an exclusivity inference. Without a stress on ‘i, the particle effectively functions as a conjunction.
Intonation determines whether the sentence has an exclusivity inference. Without a stress on ‘i, the particle effectively functions as a conjunction.
Preferable to use a connective. With a list-like intonation with multiple conjuncts continuing after “daskala”, it may be natural. In general the juxtaposition case is dispreferred.
The sentence may be felicitous if it is embedded under “I guess” or I think
The sentence may be felicitous if it is embedded under “I guess” or I think
Again, the juxtaposition is not perfect. It would be more natural in the following sequence, where there is explicit contrast. Still a pause after giatros is preferable.

Standalone (without any continuation), both sentences are infelicitous. However, with a continuation like “actually both of them are”, there is a slight contrast. Both of them are in principle felicitous with the continuation, but the second one (with ‘i) sounds more appropriate. Continuation: Vasika, kai oi dio einai giatroi.

Both would be infelicitous without any continuation. However, with a continuation like “he may be both”, both are in principle felicitous although the one with ‘i is more appropriate.
